subject: Re: [junit] Re: now it is almost working....
msgSnippet: You need to review basic principles of Java files, classpath, etc if you have any hoping of being successful with this project. In general, remove all
messageBody:
You need to review basic principles of Java files, classpath, etc if
you have any hoping of being successful with this project.

In general, remove all "package" statements from your code, remove the
"import X;" line from the test file, put both .java files in the same
directory, and try to compile again. But you really need to learn the
basics of Java before moving on to advanced topics like JUnit etc.

Wayne

On 10/23/06, Magnus <t703093@...> wrote:
>
>
> Hello,
>
>
> so I have to do it like this:
>
> //TestX.java
> package example.junit4;
> import X;
>
> import org.junit.Test;
> import static org.junit.Assert.assertEquals;
> import junit.framework.JUnit4TestAdapter;
>
> public class TestX{
> @Test
> public void numbersAboveOneShouldGetDoubled() throws
> Exception {
>
> assertEquals(4, new X().met(2));
> assertEquals(6, new X().met(3));
> assertEquals(8, new X().met(4));
> }
>
> @Test
> public void numbersEqualOrBelowOneShouldYield666() throws
> Exception {
>
> assertEquals(666, new X().met(1));
> assertEquals(666, new X().met(0));
> assertEquals(666, new X().met(-4));
> }
> }
>
>
>
>
>
> now it should be able to see class X?
>
> Still I have problems compiling this java-file with javac:
>
> I get '.' expected at
> import X;
>
>
> Magnus
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>

> > > int num = number;
> > > if (num <= 1)
> > > return num*2;
> > > else{
> > > return 666;
> > > }
> > > }
